content:
GB 133 LSP Papers of Leonard Sheldrake 1922-1966 Finding aid compiled by Graham Johnson. 1st edition The John Rylands University Library
150 Deansgate, Manchester M3 3EH England tel.: +44 (0)161 275 3764 fax: +44 (0)161 834 5574

© The John Rylands University Library, The University of Manchester, 2010

Finding aid encoded in EAD 2002 by Graham Johnson using Oxygen XML Editor v.11.1August 2010 Finding aid written in English. Finding aid compiled according to JRUL's Guide to the listing of archives (3rd edition, 2004), which is based on the General International Standard Archival Description (ISAD(G)), second edition. The University of Manchester, The John Rylands University Library GB 133 LSP Papers of Leonard Sheldrake 1922–1966 Sheldrake, Leonard, Brethren preacher 0.5 linear metres; 6 boxes. English Biographical history

Leonard Sheldrake was a Brethren preacher, author and editor. He was born in England in 1885 to John and Susan Sheldrake. His immediate family were not religious, but after the death of his father he came into contact with family members who were Baptist, and was himself baptised. As a young man he became a Sunday school superintendent, standing in for the local preacher during his absence. He moved to Canada in 1905 beginning his association with the Brethren through the Broadview assembly in Toronto. Here he became an active gospel preacher. Moving to Winnipeg, he abandoned his job working for a mail order company in 1911 to devote himself to full-time ministry. He married Ada Pearl Clapp on 20 September 1911. They moved to America in 1913 where he began writing gospel tracts, publishing them in the magazines Words of Peace and The North American Evangelist, both of which he edited. The former brought him into contact with William J. Pell who set up the Gospel Folio Press to produce this and other evangelical literature. In 1927 they created Look on the Fields to encourage missionary work abroad. He also produced three books: The Other Side of the Wall (a collection of articles reprinted from Look on the Fields), Tabernacle Types and Shadows, and Our Lord Jesus Christ: a Plant of Renown, which is still in print. He died on 8 May 1952.

 Archival history

The collection was passed to Jeffrey Staley by Leonard Sheldrake’s grandson Bill Sheldrake, who inherited the collection on the death of Ruth Sheldrake, Leonard’s daughter in 1995.

 Immediate source of acquisition

Jeffrey Staley

 Scope and content

An extensive collection of material relating to the life and evangelical activities of Leonard Sheldrake. There is correspondence from Sheldrake to his business partner William J. Pell, with whom he set up the Gospel Folio Press for the production of Christian literature, particularly that concerned with the activities of missionary activity abroad. There is correspondence to his wife and family whilst Sheldrake was engaged in touring America as a roving evangelist. There are magazines, handwritten notes, sermons and articles connected with this activity, and a large detailed scrapbook detailing his activities as an itinerant preacher.

The collection would be of interest to historians of evangelical activity in America, especially in the 1930s, to those interested in the history of Brethrenism, and in Christian missionary activity in general.

 System of arrangement

The collection has been arranged into 8 series: Correspondence Magazines Photograph Notes and Articles Typescripts and Notes Diaries Annotated Bible Scrapbook

Preferred Citation

Papers of Leonard Sheldrake, LSP/1/1 etc., John Rylands University Library, University of Manchester.

 Restrictions on access

The collection is open to any accredited reader.

 Restrictions on use

Photocopies and photographic copies of material in the archive can be supplied for private study purposes only, depending on the condition of the documents.

A number of items within the archive remain within copyright under the terms of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988; it is the responsibility of users to obtain the copyright holder's permission for reproduction of copyright material for purposes other than research or private study.

Prior written permission must be obtained from the Library for publication or reproduction of any material within the archive. Please contact the Head of Special Collections, John Rylands University Library, 150 Deansgate, Manchester, M3 3EH.

 Index terms Sheldrake Leonard 1885-1952 Brethren preacher America Christianity Missionaries Plymouth Brethren Constituent Records LSP/1 Correspondence 1922-1966 401 Letters and 1 postcard

The correspondence of Leonard Sheldrake to his business partner, William J. Pell, and to his wife and family.

In keeping with the original order of the correspondence, the letters were organised as follows: Letters from Sheldrake to William J. Pell. Letters from Sheldrake to his wife Pearl and other family members. Letters from Sheldrake to his daughter Ruth.

LSP/1/1 Bundle of Letters 1922-1936 and n.d 70 letters

Handwritten letters from Leonard Sheldrake to his business partner and fellow evangelist William J. Pell, mostly concerning the activities of the Gospel Folio Press. One of the letters has a typescript letter attached from J.W. Swarz to Sheldrake. Included among the letters is a typescript article by Richard Sheldrake entitled 'A word of exhortation', a detailed handwritten list (possibly a list of themes for preaching), a short note in verse form [the words of a hymn?], a handwritten draft of a 'Notice' advertising the magazine Words of Peace, and a brief typescript note citing Sheldrake's intention to obtain '10,000 French testaments for Quebec'.

Most of the letters are undated. There is an envelope with one letter dated 1923, and a letter dated 14 Dec 1922; the last letter in the bundle is dated 23 Sep 1936.

 LSP/1/2 Bundles of Letters 1930-1952 275 letters Some of the early letters have been marked with a pink highlighter pen.

Extensive collection of handwritten letters from Leonard Sheldrake to his wife Pearl Sheldrake, and other members of his immediate family. Includes three typescript letters and 3 telegrams. Also included is a handwritten note in a child's hand to 'Dear Daddy' from 'Your son, Leonard'.

There is a copy of Words of Love, 27 Jul 1952 containing an obituary of Sheldrake by 'Ruth S.', a photocopy of a photograph [from a newspaper?] with Sheldrake and others during the 'Kentucky flood disaster, 1937'. There are printed memorial cards for Samuel Kauffman (d. 16 Jun 1941), Albert Edward Bennett (d. 18 Apr 1940), Margaret Brodie Johnson (d. 27 Jan 1942), Mrs. Leonard Sheldrake (d. 5 Mar 1966), and a printed notice for '55th Annual Conference of Christians' held in Kansas City on 14 and 15 Nov 1942.

As well as family and personal matters, the letters contain detailed accounts of Sheldrake's travels and his evangelical activities, with reflections on the success or otherwise of their meetings. He also occasionally reflects on items in the local and national news and political developments of the time.

 LSP/1/3 Bundle of Letters 1926-1966 56 letters and 1 postcard

Mostly letters from Leonard Sheldrake to his daughter Ruth concerning family matters and giving accounts of gospel meetings. There is a letter to Pearl Sheldrake dated 21 Sep 1926, and letters to family signed 'Daddy'. There is a letter from Pearl Sheldrake to Leonard, and 6 letters from other individuals to Ruth.

There are also four handwritten cards 'To my beloved Pearl', and a bundle of printed items: Copy of Look to the Fields, Jul 1927. Copy of tract: What do you People Believe ... Cutting: 'Tom Wilkie Talks to 500 Youth at Sunday School Picnic'. Newspaper cutting on betrothal of Miss Sheryl L. DeBoer and Ronald E. Smith. Printed Christmas card. Newspaper cutting on death of Pearl Sheldrake in car accident. Memorial tributes to Pearl Sheldrake.

LSP/2 Magazines 1956, 1972 and n.d. 3 items

3 magazines: Interest, Jul-Aug 1972, includes article on 'The Story of Will Pell & the Gospel Folio Press'. Publicity booklet: Kansas City Area of Missouri. Moody Monthly, Mar 1956.

LSP/3 Photograph n.d. 1 item 25 x 20.5 cm

Photograph of large group of individuals (adults and children) with lake and trees in background. 'Leonard Sheldrake' written in ink on reverse.

 LSP/4 Notes and Articles 1923, Mar 1943 and n.d. 5 items [? unclear - loose sheets]

Handwritten notes, possibly sermons, and typescript description of activities of 'Gospel Bus' with annotations, and additional handwritten text.

 LSP/5 Typescripts and notes 1951-1952 and n.d. 7 items

Drafts of articles [?], handwritten note signed 'Daddy'. Two copies of typescript 'Monthly Ministry Letter' signed by Sheldrake and dated January 1951 and April 1952.

Printed booklet The Other side of the Wall, 'by Leonard Sheldrake'. This is a memorial volume of writings by Sheldrake, which begins with a sketch of his life and an account of his funeral service.

14 pages of typescript reminiscences [by Sheldrake?] about assemblies in Argentina.

 LSP/6 Diaries 1936-1937 and 1939 2 items

Diaries and notebooks of Leonard Sheldrake.

 LSP/6/1 Diary 1939 1 volume

Account of daily activities, including itinerary and subjects of sermons.

 LSP/6/2 Notebook 1936-1937 1 volume

Inside cover: 'Bible Outlines'. Begins as notes on Biblical subjects, turns into an occasional diary with outlines of activities.

 LSP/7 Annotated Bible n.d. Poor condition: binding detached, pages crumbling

Sheldrakes's personal Bible. Cuttings pasted into front pages.

 LSP/8 Scrapbook 1931-1939 1 scrapbook and various loose items Pages loose, some of scrapbook pages in poor condition and crumbling around edges.

Extensive scrapbook produced by Sheldrake, in the main illustrative of his activities as an travelling preacher in the United States during the 1930s. The scrapbook is annotated throughout.

At the front is a large photograph of Sheldrake holding an old Bible.

The scrapbook contains: Photographs of individuals, groups, chapels, gospel vans, gospel tents and motor cars. Advertising leaflets and notices drawing attention to gospel meetings. Cards, photographic postcards and evangelical tracts. Newspaper cuttings of meetings, activities, cartoons, obituaries, and incidents and events coinciding with his visits to particular places. Photographs and press cuttings of missionaries in Northern Rhodesia, China, Syria, France, Angola and Czechoslovakia. Maps, tickets and travel details. Printed records of services. Letters to Sheldrake related to his activities.

There is also a collection of loose material of the same type, presumably for inclusion in the scrapbook.
